doc.title: One statistic in Luxury which has the highest correlation with China growth has turned positive. Luxury handbags from Europe into China has the highest correlation to sector growth in China and has ju
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/GS Equity Radar Greenshoots in China Luxury Bank multiples French confidence and key research from the weekGS Equity Rad_2025-08-29

passages.text: One statistic in Luxury which has the highest correlation with China growth has turned positive. Luxury handbags from Europe into China has the highest correlation to sector growth in China and has just turned positive (as of July) for the first time since January 2024. Louise Singlehurst looks at these correlations in her Macro Tracker this week (see table below) and overall China data look a bit better, supporting her view that the region stabilises off a low base in 2H. This is key for the LVMH Buy (on Conviction List; our Going Against the Grain podcast episode looks at why we think LVMH will outperform in the next upcycle, see here).

Banks - what is the right P/E? Chris Hallam looks at the sector post \(50\%\) YTD rally and concludes the Better for Longer backdrop can persist. While Chris receives ample incoming queries on valuation now that the sector has passed \(9x\) P/E and \(1x\) P/B, his table below reminds us that in similar set- ups banks traded at \(11x\) . Also worth remembering that banks which are earning the same returns today, are doing so against a much higher capital base.

France's unexpected confidence vote. We hosted a webcast with first takes from Economics (most likely outcome is the government losing the confidence vote and being forced to resign which could also make further sovereign credit rating downgrades more likely), equity strategy (French domestic are most exposed given the outperformance they had YTD before the news) and rates strategy (expects muted OAT volatility, elections main risk). We were also joined by GBM colleagues to give colour from Sales & Trading on baskets (GSXEFRDO is their French Domestic basket) and financial spec sales. Replay here.

September conferences. Busy schedule in the coming weeks. Virtual on Monday so there is time to join the Utilities IR Back to School day. In London, we have European Medtech & Healthcare (3- 4 Sept), European Real Estate Equity & Debt (15 Sept), European Communacopia (16- 17 Sept). Globally key conferences include Global Retailing Conference (3- 4 Sept, NYC), Communacopia & Technology Conference (6- 11 Sept, San Francisco) and German Corporate Conference (22- 24 Sept, Germany).

Exhibit 1: China trends in July appear to show signs of improvement in the region, but Louise Singlehurst notes Real Estate prices remain challenging
GREATER CHINA - Macro Tracker3Q234Q231Q242Q243Q244Q241Q252Q253Q25E2Q TrendRSQ
We filter this week's research through the merchandising lens to highlight actionable ideas and pull out some themes / key messages which we think are important - click into the report more!
Two bank downgrades (see sector refresh section for more on sector views): Deutsche Bank to Neutral and Commerzbank AG to Sell on valuation

Banks - Still constructive after c50% rally YTD as 'Better for Longer' backdrop holds (steeper rate curve and more range bond terminal rate expectations support NII outlook, better growth in Europe underpinned by German fiscal spend, and insulation from tariffs vs. rest of market). Buy ratings: UBS, ING (on Conviction List), Lloyds, Barclays, BIRG, JB, NatWest, Santander, KBC, Nordea, DNB, UniCredit, Intesa and HSBC. See also: Assessing the implications of potential changes to UK bank taxes

Capital Goods - Outperformed the market and at 25% PE premium leaving no near- term upside on the average stock but remain constructive on the medium term supported by capex tracker which is positive for Conviction List name Atlas Copco (listen to our 'Capex Revival in Europe?' podcast with Daniela Costa and more here).
UK Insurance London market - Softening market conditions evident in H1 shifts but 3 Buys: Beazley (cyber exposure), Lancashire (reserve releases) and Hiscox (Retail segment).

Luxury Macro Tracker - Europe to China Leather handbag imports are \(+7\%\) in July, the first positive month since Jan 2024, the highest correlation to underlying sector growth. Forecast stabilisation in 2H off low base. Buy LVMH (on Conviction List) which has tended to outperform the industry as the cycle recovers (as discussed here). For high- end exposure, Buy BCU and ZGN. Remain cautious on turnarounds against tough backdrop (Sell Kering).
Beverages - NABCA data for July shows US Spirits improved but Diageo (Neutral) underperforms.

Georgina Fraser reiterated her Buy rating (on CL) on Novonesis following results post the c8% sell off on the day, she continues to expect Novonesis to deliver the highest OSG in the coverage. Georgina also thinks 3Q will stand out notably vs. ingredients peers. Buy with c. \(+30\%\) upside, trading at 2.1x PEG vs. an average of 4.4x for the other ingredient names.
Luxury Macro Tracker above supportive for Buy- rated LVMH (on CL).

Nvidia (Buy) - Reported 2Q in- line relative to elevated expectations; resumption of China business remains less clear as uncertainty remains surrounding both H20 product demand and export licenses for Blackwell; see meaningful upside heading into 2026 with our EPS estimates \(\sim 10\%\) above the Street; Buy. Shares were down \(
Buy thesis which is outlined in initiation earlier this month; consensus does not model acquisitions leaving GSe 5- 10% ahead on revenues FY27E- 29E.

Going Against the Grain. Anti- consensus ideas. If you want 30 minutes on what the company does, what drives the earnings, why we like it and our anti- consensus focus, listen here for: Repsol, Vonovia, LVMH, Bayer and Adecco.
Themes We are Watching. Capex Revival in Europe? / Unpacking AI from a Generalist Perspective: Latest Abilities, Costs, and More
Macro. French confidence vote - what next? / GOAL 2H Outlook: Goldilocks and the three bears

French confidence vote - Announced for 8 Sept (not expected), webcast addressed implications of different governments on budgets, growth and potential for systemic risk (listen here). See also Economics (growth forecast unchanged), equity strategy (French domestics most exposed and have outperformed into event) and rates strategy.
2Q Europe earnings season came in just above the low bar - Companies missing earnings were penalised more than usual (more than we have seen in c.20 years) while beats saw little share price upside.

US 2Q US earnings show strong revenue growth for S&P 500 but weaker economy- wide activity - Strong revenue growth for the S&P 500 but weaker economy- wide activity; rebound in sentiment around the consumer but the H2 outlook still appears challenging.
In case you missed it last week, Jackson Hole notes from economics (FOMC returns to flexible inflation targeting), rates and FX. See also Lessons from the Papers Presented at Jackson Hole

Comparing mutual fund and hedge fund positioning - Both have generated solid \(8\%\) YTD according to data from GS Prime Services, despite a challenging beta environment earlier this year and a sharp short squeeze more recently. However, while mutual funds have cut cash allocations back to near- record lows, hedge fund net leverage remains near its 5- year average. Both generally agree on sectors, with Health Care and Industrials ranking among the most overweight sectors. There are seven "shared favorites" this quarter: APP, CRH, MA, SCHW, SPOT, V, VRT.
A likely new normal for HY dispersion - Despite index level spreads hovering near all- time tights, dispersion in the HY market remains stubbornly high

Stress testing our oil price forecast amidst stable OECD stocks - Estimate \(\) 6\(of upside risk to our Brent 2026 forecast (\) 56 by 2026) from a 0.5mb/d faster pace of China restocking than in our baseline
China: What do local clients think about the economy? - Most still expecting authorities to deliver the \(5\%\) growth target.
China Musings: Why the liquidity- driven rally has further to go
Global Electric Vehicles: What's Next X - Shift in the direction of US environmental regulations will have a major positive earnings impact on traditional automakers (margins up 2- 3pp).
Apple Inc. (Buy) - September 9 event preview: expected to announce new products including iPhone 17 series, updated Apple Watches, iOS 26
US Diversified Financials - Broadly healthy outlook, elevated valuations
US Clean Technology: Solar - US court declares moratorium on solar imports illegal, but possibility for appeal
China/Southeast Asia Data Centers 2Q wrap - Next few months critical to watch in terms of order volume recovery for China AI infrastructure.
Saudi Arabia Banks - Strong loan growth continues, but tight liquidity and deposit mix deterioration limits profitability.
Catch up with our latest webcasts, podcasts and videos. Visit the Audibles page.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/ divided (PD), EV/EBITDA, EV/FC and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on

an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR).
